sp.p: I do it with more pleasure than I shall take to see those two Insatiate Devils walk to the Gallows together.

sp.speaker: Seren.
sp.p: My Dear, let me intreat my Mother's Pardon, tho she be ill, she is kin to me.

sp.speaker: Gun. Iun.
sp.p: Canst thou ask any thing, and be deny'd● she shall not suffer, but must be contented, to end her days in some Religious House.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Where I will spend my time in Cursing you.

sp.speaker: Gus. Iun.
sp.p: But for this fellow, he shall have pleasure, to tug an Oar, the Gallies want such Vermin, look to him Officers.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, let me have the Charge of him, I'll hang for him if he escapes me.

sp.speaker: Gus. Iun.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, how can you sleep midst so much Joy, Sir, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gus. Sen.
sp.p: Let me alone, I am resolv'd never to wake till you give me my Lands again.

sp.speaker: Gus. Iun.
sp.p: You have 'em, Sir, pray wake.

sp.speaker: Gus. Sen.
sp.p: Cud's me, and so I have, who's there Iemmy, prithee how cam'st thou here, and such a Crow'd about thee? Heyday, with thy Mistress too, what art thou Married Iemmy?

sp.speaker: Gus. Iun.
sp.p: We are joyn'd by Heaven, and by her Father, Sir, and now desire your Blessing.

sp.speaker: Gus. Sen.
sp.p: Heav'n bless thee: But don't forget the 200 l. a year Iemmy?

sp.speaker: Gus. Iun.
sp.p: You will have no occasion for it, Sir, your own Estate will be surrender'd you.

sp.speaker: Gus. Sen.
sp.p: How! my own Estate, what my 1500 a year?

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Ay marry shall it, Sir, here's my hand for't.

sp.speaker: Gus. Sen.
sp.p: Why then Heaven send thee thy Eyes again.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: I never was without 'em make me thankful.

sp.speaker: Gus. Sen.
sp.p: Nay, nay, thou wer't always a cheating Rogue, that I must needs say for thee.

sp.speaker: Gus. Iun.
sp.p: Come my Serena, now I'm truly Blest, let's to the Priest, and when our hands are joyn'd, I'll to my Friend, and get thy Father's Pardon. This is the happiest day of all my Life.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: And mine thank Heav'n, for I have lost my Wife.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth ACT.

div.head: ACT V. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: THe Court is full of Joy, Mirth flows about, Masques are prepar'd, and every one seems Happy, but I who ought to have the largest share, sit like a sullen Fiend 'mongst Choirs of Angels, as if I envied 'em their vast delight, what can this mean, my Soul is on the Rack, and yet I cannot give a reason for it. Where are those mighty pleasures I propos'd in the Embraces of the Charming Bride? they're vanish'd, I have lost the glittering dream, and walk to Horror and Eternal Darkness.
sp.stage: Lightning from under the Stage, and a Fiery Figure flies up.
sp.p: Ha! what was that, something went glazing by me, it had the Form of Artan wrap'd in Fire? Oh, that cursed Fiend, 'tis he disturbs my Joys, that fatal Contract ruins soul and body; what have I done, why, why did I marry, why have I made the Innocent Mercella a wretched partner in my World of woes? see where she comes, that pretty blooming Flower, whom I pluck'd untimely from the stalk, and now 'twill drop and perish.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: My dear Love, why have you left the Company so strangely? why when the Court seems nothing but delight, when every one is wrapt in Joy and Pleasure, do you, the happy cause of all our Transports, fly thence as if you envied us the blessing?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Why dost thou wrong me? by my Love I swear, I have no Content, but what is placed in thee, and sure hereafter I shall find no pleasure greater then I possess in these dear Arms.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p:
Pray do not flatter me, you cannot Love me and be thus sad upon your Wedding day; may be you are troubled that you are matched so high, and think perhaps my birth will make me proud, indeed I'll be a very humble Wife, or if you think I marry not for Love
but only in Obedience to my Uncle, I will convince you by such tender proofs, you shall acknowledge none can Love beyond me.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Otender Innocence, I do not doubt thee, I know thy Beauty cannot shrowd a falshood, where is my Royal Uncle?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: In the Garden, viewing the Fountains that are newly made, and waits for you to see 'em.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: I'll go with you: O my Marcella, prithee do not chide me. There's something troubles me, a heavy load lies on my heart, but by thy Charming self, I cannot guess from whence the cause proceeds, unless the sudden Joy I find in thee, has overpowered my Spirits.

div.stage: (As they are going off, Artan rises in a horrid shape, Her. starts back)

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: Why do you start my Love and tremble thus? What is't your Eyes are fixt on?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: I had forgot; I cannot go with you, 'tis near the hour I am to make a great account with Heaven, and sollitude is fittest for Devotion, that done, you shall behold me full of Joy, or everlasting Sorrow, prithee leave me.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: I know my duty and I will obey you. But stay not long.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Not long, unless for ever. Tell me thou Gorgeon, that has made me stone, whence or what art thou?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Artan.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Why com'st thou?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: To inform thee, this moment is thy last: You must with me.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: My time's not yet expired.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Deluded Fool, thou had'st no time but what was in my Will, I might have cut thy Brittle-Thread of Life the very moment that this deed was sign'd; look there and see what time's allowed thee, and Curse thy self for thy unthinking folly.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p:
May I believe my Eyes, O wretched Fool, how hast thou plunged thy self into perdition, this was the fatal blow my heart presaged, and this the wretched end of all my Joys! O dismal Marriage night! Unhappy Bridegroom! must then thy Bridal Bed be Sulphurous flames, and Fiends perform thy Hymencial rites? instead of my Marcella's soft Embraces, must I ashing Furies Clasp me in their Arms? O thou great injur'd power I have Offended, strike, strike
me to the Center, and make my Soul as Mortal as my Body.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Leave off your Idle Prayers, or by that power I serve, and you are ty'd to Worship, thou sha't not tread the Earth a moment longer.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Fiend thou li'st, thou that not dare to touch me, what power hadst thou to Buy or I to Sell, that which was none of my own, I had no Soul at my dispose, for it was bought before, bought, at a Rate so high, that the whole World weighs not a Grain of the vast price was paid for't.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: This will not save you, since you have free-will, and by that free will thus, as'twas sign'd to me. I do expect performance of the Deed.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Shall the bare setting of my name condemn me? how many Wretches, in their Lust and Riots, have made a gift, seal'd firm with Imprications? Wretches for Perjury, and foul Extoration, make by their Crimes a Deed as strong as mine: Nay even the murderer, whose purple stains fix to his Soul, and mark it with. Damnation, and true Penitent Tears, 'tis Cleansed and Whiten'd for a brighter Being.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Fool, I'll not give thee Leisure to Repent, nor sha't thou have a moment more to breath, by all the Ashy Treasuries of death, I have not power to stir, what can this mean, he bears some holy relick sure about him, or he is fix'd on Consectared ground. Come from that place.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: No infernal, never, perhaps the ground is Sacred that I tread on, if so, I will not stir, but rooted fast, I'll stand a Monument of true Devotion, and here exprie in prayers.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Slave, I'll blast thee.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Thou art the Slave, not I. A Sacred inspiration fills my Soul, and bids me dare thy worst, ha! Let me think the very day, on which my Father dy'd, his Confessor, Physition of his Soul come to me, and delivered me a Paper, which I have wore ever since next my heart: My Son, said he, take this, and when thou find'st thou art upon the very brink of ruin, open that Paper and thou'lt find inclos'd that which will make thy Enemies fly from thee: now is the time, I'm just upon the Brink, and here before me stands my greatest Enemy; thus then I break the seal, and thus unfold the Sacred mistery.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Tempest, Lightning, Thunder, Plagues seize thy Marrow, give me back the Contract.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: No, I will tear it to as many peices as thou hast ruin'd Souls. Avant cursed. Tempter, hence to thy native Hell, and howl in flames.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Perdition, Furies, why am I thus fool'd, I shall be made the sport of every Fiend, and hooted through each Region, they will make me the very Owl of Hell, to sculk in Corners, and every meager Ghost will Chatter at me. I cannot bear the thought, Convulsions gnaw thee,
sp.l: Aches contract thy Bones, that thou may'st know
As great a Plegue above as I shall find below.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: 'Tis done ', the Victory's obtain'd at last, and I will bravely keep the field I've won, I'll fix to this Sacred standard on my heart, and never fear success under this Banner.

div.stage: Enter Duke, Marcella, Gusman Senior, Gusman Junior, Bond, Pedro, &c.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Nephew, have you got done your Contemplations? you look more Gay and Lively than you did, I do suppose it was your excess of Joy, that over-power'd your Spirits.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: I confess, my breast is full of Joy; O my Marcella, forgive me that my Soul could harbour sadness upon this day, but I'll convince my Fair one, that I had than as great a cause of Sorrow as now I have for Pleasure.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: My dear Lord, my Joy or Grief does all depend on you, and when you're Pleas'd I'm Happy.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: See Nephew, here's more visitors to see you, and one that has but newly found his Eyes, he took a happy day to make his Peace in thee, which at the intreaty of your Friend I have Granted.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Your Goodness makes me more your humble debtor; my Friend I wish you Joy, for I perceive a cheerfulness, that says you have gained your wishes.

sp.speaker: Gus. Iun.
sp.p: I have gained all I wish.

sp.speaker: Gus. Sen.
sp.p: I have got my Estate again, and now I want nothing but a longer Lease of Life, that I might have time enough to spend it again.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Seignior Bond, I hope you'l live hereafter with more Justice, believe me, 'tis the surest way to thrive. There's a small reckoning betwixt you and me, but I forgive you freely.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Sir, I thank, and will make it my whole Life's study to deserve your Favour.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Now for thee, honest Pedro.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Good lack, I was afraid you had forgot me. 'Tis a Plaguy trick you Courtiers have got never to Remember past services.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Fear not Pedro, I'll see thee prefer'd.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I thank your Grace.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Come Nephew, seat your self, and you his Friends, the Masque has waited for us.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: We attend your Grace.

div.stage: The Scene changes to a Beautiful Garden, &c.

div.head: ENDIMION The Man in the Moon. A MASQUE.
div.stage:
Menalcas, Dorus, Damon, Alexis
with other Shepherds and some Shepherdesses are discover'd, and some of them Dancing.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: COme Shepherds, 'tis Night, and our Flocks are in Fold,
Come Dorus and Damon, we'll haste from the Cold.
To Coridon's Cottage we'll go,
There the Liquor does merrily flow.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Stay Menalcas, prethee stay,
Endimion us'd to come this way,
Let us for Endimion stay,

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: Let us for Endimion stay,

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Endimion's Flocks all go astray,
Their Master strays as much as they,
For you Bright Moon Endimion sights,
For her he fondly pines and dies,
Pitty poor Endimion's pain,
Poor Endimion! hopeless Swain!

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: Poor Endimion! hopeless Swain!

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Why should not a Lover
This Whining give over,
Since nothing but sorrow it yields.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Rich Egon's Brown Daughter,
Has made my Mouth Water,
But by Pan, not for her, but her Flock and her Fields.
See yonder he lies
Sleep closes his Eyes,
I'll wake him—

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: No Dorus, no, let him alone,
I'll wake him—
No Dorus, no let him Sleep on,
Sleep is the Lovers only Ease,
By Sleep, of quiets he pertakes,
Gay Dreams of Bliss, his Fancy please,
But when they fly, Dispair awakes:
To those short Ioys the Swain we'll leave,
The only Comfort, we can give.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: To Corydon's Cottage we'll go,
There the Liquor does merrily flow.
Sleep Shepherd, 'till thou wak'st in Ioy,
I've kindly wounded Cynthia's Heart,
Let coming Bliss thy Thoughts Employ,
She comes to Sooth, thy raging smart,
Sleep Shepherd till thou wak'st in Ioy.

sp.speaker: Endi.
sp.l: She comes, my Goddess come,— I dream—
'Tis not forwaking Eyes
To see such wondrous Ioys,
Ioys like my Mighty Love, extream,
All Heaven is round me,— O, I Dream!

sp.speaker: Cynthia.
sp.l: Awake Endimion, from above
Thy Cynthia comes to Crown thy Love.

sp.speaker: Endimion.
sp.l: Oh I dream!
Sleep does my wishing Soul deceive,
I wou'd, but dare not Believe.
I Dream!

sp.speaker: Cynthia.
sp.l: In thy soft Dreams true Ioys appear;
Awake, and see thy Cynthia here.

div.stage:
Endimion
Starts and Catches her in his Arms.
She's here, I have my Goddess here.
Cynthia and Endimion come in Attended by a Train of Stars her Concomitants.

sp.speaker: Cynthia.
sp.l: Here, here, we'll Regin in full Delight,
And thou Swain shalt Rule the Night.

sp.speaker: Endi.
sp.l: Happy Beings here conceal
All the Pleasures, which they steal,
'Tis the Scandal makes the Fault,
Still she's Chaste who such is thought,
Love's delights are always sweet,
But when Secret, Sweeter yet.
Happy Being, &c.

div.stage: To the Grand Chorus Cinthia's Celestial Attendants repeat the last Six Lines.
